Fields.DialogueText: Goooooooood morning, Capitaine!
Getting there. Couple gallons of black coffee ought to make it a great morning.
Ha! Ha! Ha! Good one, sir! Tell me, how many lavatories are on this fabulous ship?
Shouldn't you, of all people, know the answer to that question?
Bear with me, Capitaine. Each one has a mirror in it, correct?
Yes. What are you getting at?
With your permission, I'd like to convert one of them into a vanity. Strictly for myself, of course.
And why would you think that's appropriate on a warship... in the middle of a war?
Because even war needs a little beauty, sir. Hmm... it looks like the Morganas are approaching.

Fields.MenuText: Wars need to be won.
Prove yourself in battle, and I might honor your request.
War isn't supposed to be pretty.

Fields.DialogueText: So serious, sir.
You have yourself a deal, Capitaine!
Just a sliver of lovely is all I ask, sir. Sir? Where are you going?
@BATTLE
Ha! Those Morganas didn't stand a chance.
That did seem a bit too easy...
Enough of a victory to rate a vanity?
A promise is a promise. Never thought I'd be commanding the prettiest ship in the fleet.
Who better to do it than the smoothest-spoken captain?
This sauce is delicious. I can't stop eating it. I didn't think our cooks had the chops to make something so savory.
That's because I had a hand in preparing it, Capitaine. The recipe has been up here in this pretty little head of mine since I was young.
What's it called?
It's Béarnaise sauce, of course. Béarnaise food is the best in the world, and that's a fact.
It certainly enhances the flavor of the steak. Now then, I know you're trying to butter me up. Why?
Why, Capitaine? I can't believe you would even suggest such a thing! En toute sincérité, I'm a little insulted.

Fields.MenuText: There is always something crafty going on in that little head of yours, so let's have it.
You're right, I apologize.
Forget it, let's change the subject.

Fields.DialogueText: Nonsense! Can't a girl just make a nice little meal for her capitaine?
That's better. Apology accepted.
Okay. Um... so, how about that Hitler, huh? What an idiot, am I right, Capitaine?
Uh...
Hold that thought, sir! Morganas heading our way!
@BATTLE
Since you awoke.
An expression, Capitaine. If I'd awakened when I was launched, it would have been there.
Where did I put that thing? I know I left it was here yesterday! Damn!
Did you call, Capitaine?
No, but as long as you're here, you wouldn't happen to know where my pocket watch has gone off to, would you?
Uh, I wasn't aware you even had one, sir. What did it look like?
Hold on. You said "did."
Huh? So?
That's implying past tense, as if it's no longer around.
Oh, Capitaine, I meant "does." Grammar was never my best subject, sir.
Clearly...
I'd be more than happy to assist you in finding the timepiece, sir.  Unfortunately, we have a Morgana fleet headed in our direction. To arms!
@BATTLE
Now that that's over with...

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you're the one who took the damn thing.
Since you're no longer busy, why not help me search for it?
Go attend your duties, Béarn. I need more time searching for my blasted timepiece.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine! I may be gorgeous, charming, and chock full of moxie, but I'm no thief!
Unfortunately, duty calls, I'm afraid.
Bon. Off I go, then.
That girl is an interesting one...
Your move, Capitaine.
Damn.
Not feeling as confident as you were a few minutes ago, are you?

Fields.MenuText: I'll just move this pawn here.
Perhaps I'll take this rook two squares to the right...
Maybe I'll just take the game board and toss it across the room.

Fields.DialogueText: Sloppy, Capitaine. Very sloppy. That pawn is now mine.
Are you suuuuuure? Perhaps it is there to be taken.
Ha! I didn't anticipate that move! Well played, Capitaine.
It would seem the tides have turned.
I'd say so. Hopefully your strategies will be more effective against the incoming Morganas.
Blast! Let's get to the bridge!
@BATTLE
In a way, this war is beginning to feel like a global game of chess, sir.
Is that so? If the Morganas have a strategy, I haven't figured it out.
Control the center of the board and you control the game. If your world is the chessboard, what could be more central than the oceans?
Making their game... what?
Whatever it is, we're still learning the rules. But we certainly played better today!
One hopes...

La pendule fait tic-tac-tic-tic
Les oiseaux du lac pic-pac-pic-pic...
What is Miss Béarn doing over there?
Uh, it looks like she's... running laps around the flight deck, sir.
I can see that. But, why is she doing it?
To stay fit, sir?

Quand note coeur fait boum
Tout avec lui dit-
-gah!
And... she just tripped over the side of the carrier.
Oh for the love of...! Somebody throw her a life jacket!
Sir! Morgana ships approaching, dead ahead!

Fields.MenuText: Damn it. Fine, I'll get her!
You there! Yes, the one pointing at himself! Go in and get our Belle out of the drink! That's an order!
Are you all right down there? Where are you?

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate the sentiment, Capitaine.
There's no need to go to that much effort.
I'm right here, Capitaine, safe and sound.
You do remember that I'm capable of floating, correct?
Ah... yes.
@BATTLE
Are you sure you're all right, Béarn?
I'm fine, sir. A little soggy, but, other than that, I'm perfect. I needed a quick cooldown anyway after my jog.
What are we eating tonight? Running makes me famished! Say, did I ever tell you that I was supposed to be a battleship...?
Oh, goodness...
Béarn! You're okay?
Bonjour, Capitaine!
And bonjour to you, too.
Something on your mind?
Do you like to gamble, sir?

Fields.MenuText: Not usually during wartime. The odds always change.
Occasionally, but this isn't really the time.
Shouldn't you be monitoring the ship's functions?

Fields.DialogueText: Sage advice, sir. But...
There's always time for tempting fate, Capitaine.
I'm quite skilled in multitasking, sir. It's practically a prerequisite of a Belle.
Come now. It's just a friendly little wager, sir. Now then, there's a Morgana fleet currently about fourteen kilometers away...
What?!
Oh, don't worry, Capitaine, they won't be within range for some time now.
I'm going to the bridge.
I'll bet you that if those Morganas fire first, I can shoot those shells down and... Hey! Come on, sir! Where's your backbone?
@BATTLE
How old are you, Béarn?
Why, Capitaine! Didn't your mother ever tell you it's impolite to ask a lady her age?
I'm afraid my naval career completely undid everything anyone ever taught me about courtesy as a child.
Quelle dommage! But why do you ask?
It's unimportant.
Oh, no, you can't just ask a girl her age and then brush it off like that! But... it looks like we'll have to continue this later. Morganas inbound!
@BATTLE
You asked why I wanted to know your age earlier.
Yes?

Fields.MenuText: I had a teacher who looked about your age.
You remind me of a woman I met once while traveling abroad.
I was just curious about whether you date your birthday to when you were laid down or when you were launched. Or something altogether different.

Fields.DialogueText: Why, Capitaine, that's just about the sweetest thing you've ever said to me.
Perhaps I am her double. Or...maybe she perished tragically, and returned to you in the form of an exquisite carrier!
Ah!
Did you, now?
She once told me that if you put your mind to something, you can achieve anything. You have that same encouraging spirit.
You must keep stunning company, Capitaine!
She was a barmaid, and we just talked about everything under the sun. Never saw her again.
All of them, Capitaine! I expect at least seven birthday parties a year!
... I probably should have seen that coming.
You see them?
Oui, Capitaine.
Damn. I was hoping it was just me. Sound the call.
Join me in a toast, Capitaine?
Very well. What do you have there?
An Armagnac brandy.
Fancy. What are we toasting to?
How about douceur de vivre! The sweetness of life.

Fields.MenuText: All right, that will do.
I'm not sure I would describe this war as sweet.
Let's just get to the alcohol.

Fields.DialogueText: Excellent! Douceur de vivre!
Aw, Capitaine... don't be so cynical.
Straight to the point! I like it!
Cheers.
And, we drink!
This is quite the smooth brandy, Béarn...
Only the best, sir! Did I ever tell you that I was supposed to be built as a battleship? Picture it: a damp winter in La Seyne, 1914...
... Zzzzzzzzz...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Someone flag that pilot in, he's all over the place!
Something's wrong... the engine's smoking! He's coming in too fast, Capitaine!
I can see that!
He's going to hit the... Oh, he's down and sliding too fast!

Fields.MenuText: Hell, he's going to slide right off the ship!
This isn't going to end well!
No!

Fields.DialogueText: Ah! My flight deck!
Oh, no! He's not going to make it!
He's starting to slow down!
Thank God! He stopped right at the edge! Get medical personnel out there now! Béarn, you're with me!
Hold it, Capitaine! Morgana fleet incoming!
Damn! Give that pilot medical attention, now!
@BATTLE
Report.
The plane's down but not out. My hull's going to need some patching on the fore and starboard, though... merde, that stings.
We'll get you fixed up. And what of our pilot?
Unconscious but stable. Engineering is still investigating the wreckage for the exact cause, sir.
Inform me the moment he wakes up.
Oui, Capitaine.
You see them?
Oui, Capitaine.
Sound the klaxon.
@BATTLE
Have any of that brandy left, Béarn?
Bien sûr, Capitaine. I always try to keep a supply on my person at all times. Here you are, sir.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you. Care to join me?
What's the latest news with the pilot?
How's the overall mood of the crew been since the incident?

Fields.DialogueText: If it's all the same to you, sir, and I can't believe I'm saying this, I'll go without.
Stable, but still unconscious, sir.
They're all a bit downtrodden, but still performing their duties as well as can be expected.
Very well. Carry on then.
Once the plane comes around I'll steal one of the mechanics and we'll ask her where it hurts.
Once the... plane? Comes around?
It's a Belle thing, Capitaine. Leave it to me.
What the-? What's that noise? Béarn? Is that you?
It sounds like metal. We better not...
Bonjour, Capitaine!

Fields.MenuText: Ah, I guess it was just you...
I could've sworn I heard something in the walls...
I think we might have some...

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, it's me, Capitaine! The most beautiful crew member on the ship! My confidence knows no bounds!
Probably your heart going pitter-patter in my presence. I tend to have that effect.
Brie? I would kill for some.
No. Never mind. What can I do for you, Béarn?
I regret to inform you that we have a Morgana fleet approaching, sir. Ha, listen to me, sounding so formal.
Very well, I'll meet you on the bridge.
Bien sûr!
Hrm, strange...
@BATTLE
Non, non, non! This can't be happening! Ugh. Try it once more!
No go, Béarn. It's jammed.
Ugh! I'd better go inform the Capitaine.
... Who won't be too happy...
Probably not. I'll need to use every one of my feminine charms to break the news.
... Uh huh.
Béarn, there you are! ... Why the sour look on your face?
Would you like the good news or the bad news first?

Fields.MenuText: What did you do now, Béarn?
What's the bad news?
What's the good news?

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't do a thing, sir!
It's one of the guns from the wrecked plane. It's jammed.
One less gun for the men to clean?
Terrific... Anything else?
Yes, Capitaine. Actually there is... It looks like Morganas are coming this way.
@BATTLE
They're putting up more of a fight. I want that gun fixed, now! We'll need every weapon available to us!
Aye, Capitaine!
Report.
The cause of the plane crash was a fuel leak. The fuel line appears to have been damaged.
Was the damage normal wear and tear?
No. The fuel line was covered with irregularly shaped holes. Nothing wears and tears like that.

Fields.MenuText: Are we talking sabotage, here?
Is there a chance the damage occurred prior to installation?
Get to the point, Béarn!

Fields.DialogueText: In a way.
Not likely, Capitaine. Those flyboys and their mechanics are thorough almost to the point of obsession.
No need for the attitude, sir!
Rats are the most likely culprits. They munched on the line, probably in mid-flight, draining the plane's fuel.
That would explain those scuffling noises in the bulkhead I've been hearing lately.
Exactement.
*ALARM*
I want you to put together a small team of seamen to lay out some traps in the problem areas after the battle. This cannot happen again.
Aye, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
Capitaine!
What is it?
The pilot, he just woke up. He's right inside here.

Fields.MenuText: Good, let's see him.
Is he coherent? Will he be able to answer some questions?
Hopefully, he'll be able to shed some more light on what happened. We need more answers.

Fields.DialogueText: Right behind you, Capitaine! Let me just fix my hair.
Hopefully?
The man suffered an intense ordeal. Try to go easy on him.
Uhhhh... my head.
Take it easy. You're in the ship's sick bay.
What... happened?
You crashed your plane. Hell, you nearly went over into the sea. You're damn lucky to be here.
Oh, God! They... were everywhere. They brought my plane down... ohhh...
What are you talking about? Damn it, he lost consciousness again.
Capitaine, Morganas inbound. We have to go.
@BATTLE
What do you think he was talking about, Capitaine?
I just really hope it wasn't rats.
Bonjour, Capitaine.
Judging by the scraping sound, it seems we still have rats loose on the ship.
It's a work in progress - you know how vermin can be. Kill one of them...

Fields.MenuText: And two take their place.
One less rat in the world.
And their death squeaks sound like a dog toy.

Fields.DialogueText: In a twisted sort of way, it just wouldn't be a vessel without them, sir.
The fewer, the better, in my humble opinion.
Yuck! That's awful, sir. I'd rather not think about it.
Maybe. I could always make them part of the crew. They could be official ranking seamen.
Sea rats, sir. But, we'd better head for the bridge.
Another Morgana attack?
Malheureusement. I'm afraid so.
@BATTLE
Just how many rodents have been trapped so far?
Um... three, sir.
That's all?
And one cockroach. I almost forgot about that one.
Humph.
Which the third rat was discovered eating.
That'll do, Béarn. I'm sure you've got it under control... somewhere I can't see or hear it.
You see them?
If I pretended not to, do you suppose there's any chance they might sink themselves in pique?
I do admire your optimism.
@BATTLE
The Morganas continue to get tougher and more cunning.
It would appear so, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: I think it's time to work on some new tactics.
Inform engineering to begin testing some new weaponry.
Continue fighting them as best we can.

Fields.DialogueText: A sound plan, sir. I'll go fetch the protractor and brandy. Oh, I almost forgot, I have something for you.
Very good, sir. I'm sure those eggheads can come up with something that will give the Morganas a hurting. Also, I think this belongs to you, Capitaine.
So, basically what we've been doing all along? By the way, isn't this yours?
What?
This. Do you recognize it?
That's... that's my pocket watch. Where did you find it?
One of the boys found it down in the engine room.
And it's ticking again. This thing hasn't worked for a single second in almost three years.
Huh, that is strange, Capitaine. I just assumed it's always functioned.
Whoever fixed this deserves a medal. It could use some spit and polish though.
We're taking on water down in cargo!
Looks like a pinhole leak! Find something to plug that up, on the double!
Hey, what about that, over there?

Fields.MenuText: It looks like an ice pick! Quick! Grab it!
Looks like a screwdriver! That might plug up the hole! Hand it over!
Forget it! We can't use it!

Fields.DialogueText: I have it! Yes, it fits! Thank goodness!
Here you go, Capitaine! Yes, it fits! That's relief.
Maybe... Yes! Bonne année, Capitaine. The cork in this bottle should just do the trick.
... What did you just do?
But I think we might have a larger problem, sir! Morganas inbound!
Right. Okay. You'd better get to the bridge if you want to defend our brandy supply.
@BATTLE
Look at you, being all irreverent! I daresay I'm rubbing off on you.
Hm? Oh. Belle trick. I convinced the hull to let me slide our makeshift plug through so I could apply it from the outside. It's exhausting, but impressive - non?
You just... I mean, it went right through the hull!
You're welcome!
Welcome back to the living. How are you feeling?
Like I was decked by a wrecking ball, sir.
Last time we spoke, you were going on about something in your plane that caused you to crash. Do you remember any of that?
Not really, sir. But there's something I need to tell you, and it's going to sound crazy.
We're in the middle of a war with ship spirits that rebuild themselves. Go ahead and tell me.
Uh... well, I wasn't alone up there, sir.
What do you mean, exactly?
There were these little... creatures messing with the engine and the interior.
I was really afraid that was what you were going to say. We found bite marks on the-
Sorry to barge in, Capitaine, but there are Morganas headed this way! You're needed on the bridge!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Where's our flyboy? He isn't resting in his cot.
Béarn, have you seen the pilot?
Please tell me that the pilot isn't dead...

Fields.DialogueText: He had to go in for some emergency surgery while we were dealing with the Morganas, Capitaine.
Yes, Capitaine. Unfortunately, he was wheeled off into surgery while we in battle.
No, of course not, sir. He had to be taken in for surgery.
Damn. Let's hope he makes it...
What do you mean we can't steer the ship?!
Navigation systems are down, sir. But see, that's okay, because the turbines shut down as well so we can't move anyway.
So we're dead in the water.
I'm sorry, Capitaine, but it looks that way. Also, your coffee percolator seems to be on the fritz.

Fields.MenuText: Of all the damn luck! How long will the repairs take?
I will not be known as the captain that lost this war to mechanical failures!
Son of...! Is there anything that actually does work on this blasted ship?!

Fields.DialogueText: Well... it's hard to say, sir. They're still determining the um, extent of the damage. As for the percolator, it might be a lost cause.
Repairs are being performed as we speak. We will get this mess sorted out, sir! But, uh, it might take a little time.
Possibly the military grade egg beater in the galley, but I'll have to double check.
That just about clinches it! I was afraid of this...
Oui. Gremlins.
... Pardon?
You wanted to see me, Capitaine?
Yeah - please have a seat. I want to hear what you have to say about gremlins.
Most of what I have to say would be extremely vulgar, Capitaine.
Okay, but... let's begin at the beginning. It sounded to me like you believe that there are real, physical creatures at work. Not metaphors for bad luck and mechanical failure, but actual things.
Mais, oui. All the Belles know they're out there - usually lurking around equipment we can't perfect.
I don't know if they showed up at the same time that we awoke or if they're older, but I swear they're real enough.
What's the hypothesis? That the pilot was flying a plane infested with the things and now they've spread on the ship? Even in this bizarre war we've got, I think that's unprecedented.
I've reviewed the course he flew. There were some very odd atmospheric anomalies along the way...
If you're telling me he flew through a rogue gremlin storm... I think my headache just got a headache.
I hope you can shake it off, Capitaine. There's a Morgana fleet incoming.
@BATTLE
Where do we go from here, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: We track down the fiends and figure out some plan to deal with them.
We're going to find every gremlin-afflicted piece of equipment and lock them up in the brig until we can figure something out.
We continue the fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds like a plan. Or at least the makings of one.
What if the brig can't hold them? What if they eat through the bars? What if they eat us? So many questions!
Whatever happens, I'm with you, Capitaine.
What's important is that we keep you afloat.
Never you fear, Capitaine. This isn't my first mechanical mishap. You know, when I was converted to a carrier they scrapped my sisters to finish me.
That's a little morbid. All of them?
All four of them! So if I ever say something out of turn, pretend it is one of those minxes and pay it no mind.
I'll...uh, do my best.
Seriously?
Oui.
No. *Seriously*?
I promise you, Capitaine. This isn't just rats.
Right. Let's say I entertain the possibility.
Of course there is. Let's hope the engines keep working as long as we need them.
Attention all personnel, this is your Belle speaking. You may have noticed lately that there have been some strange goings-on aboard the ship. Well-
Step away from the microphone, Béarn.
The crew needs to know what's going on.
If you tell the crew that there are gremlins on board, we'll lose all control. Half the crew will think we're insane and the superstitious half will think we're just doomed.
I... could see how that might be a possibility.
Just tell them it was a false alarm.
I could announce that we have a Morgana fleet headed this way.
Do we?
We do!
Oh, hell. Tell them to get to their stations.
@BATTLE
What would you have me do once the "rat" hunting volunteers are all in, sir?

Fields.MenuText: Assist them in locating and sequestering the problem regions aboard my ship. I want them found, Béarn.
Bring them to me. I'll hand out assignments. I have a score to settle with these little beasts.
Give them some brandy before you send them out. They'll need to be loosened up if they're going to stand a chance.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, aye, Capitaine! We won't let you down!
Yes! That's the spirit, sir! Show those monsters whose ship this really is!
Aye, Capitaine. I have no doubt that the men will find the vagabonds. I always wanted to use that word in a sentence.
Capitaine...
I know that tone of voice. Where are they?
... Okay.
Sound the alarm, Béarn. Other business can wait.
@BATTLE
Report. What's the latest status with the search?
Nothing too promising so far, sir. Just a few dead rats and some discouraged sailors.
Check the engine room and any area of the ship that has heavy machinery running.
Bien sûr!

Fields.MenuText: I take it your feelings about gremlins haven't changed? You still believe they're the cause of the problem?
Do you think these things might just subside? Or fade away?
They can be crafty, but we will find them. We must, if we hope to continue fighting this war.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, Capitaine. The pilot's condition confirms it, as far as I'm concerned.
It would be nice to think so, Capitaine. But I want to know more - the damage done to my boilers was too significant to wish away.
They must be. So far, they have eluded us both and I would have thought that impossible!
Okay. You'd better get back to it, then. Report to me with any changes.
Aye, sir!
I feel like I'm responsible for bringing them onboard.
No, you are not. It was just another environmental hazard - like a freak thunderstorm with teeth.
Maybe you're right, Captain.
Trust me, you are not to blame. But, onto some good news - our Belle tells me she's had some success tracking the things down and getting them contained.
That's excellent, sir! How many?
Two.
Oh, I see. Uh, there were at least seven on my plane, Captain...

Fields.MenuText: I'd say we still have some work to do.
Only five more to go, then. That's not unreasonable at all.
Following the crash, there might even be less than seven.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, we better get some more butterfly nets. Just kidding, Capitaine.
Five is cake, sir! Devil's food cake that is, if I may be so bold.
I hope so, Capitaine. A few less of those monsters the better.
Excuse the interruption, sirs, but we have Morganas inbound!
On my way!
@BATTLE
You're sure? Humans can't seem to see the damn things - even our friend here seems to be tracking them down more by instinct than perception.
I got a knock on the head, sir. Then they were there, clear as day. I would almost think I hallucinated them, but... I mean, you've seen the bite marks.
Okay. So we assume a minimum of seven.
I don't see anything but a box of some genuinely wretched-looking equipment.
Trust me - this is the root of our problem. Most of it is debris from the plane that crewmembers took for "good luck." Most of them don't remember exactly how or when, either.
And these are all of them?
We scoured every inch of this ship, so yes, I think so. And as much as I'd like to continue gawking at these future beauty pageants here, we have a Morgana fleet headed our way!
Let's go!
@BATTLE
That's one of the toughest battles we've encountered so far, sir.
I was a little worried we had met our match, for a moment there.
Hmm. You know, I think I may have an idea, Capitaine. A new tactic maybe.

Fields.MenuText: You have my full attention, Béarn.
I'll listen to your proposal, but I think I need a drink first.
If it means victory over the Morganas, then by all means, proceed.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I'll explain on the way to engineering. We'll need some assistance from them...
Make it two, Capitaine. Afterwards, we need to get to engineering. It's part of the plan.
I do believe it will, Capitaine!
*ALARM*
Where are... ah. Someone has a good eye!
Merci!
@BATTLE
Well, the Morganas are fleeing. Is it time to enact your plan, Béarn?
It is. Let's do it.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure this will work?
On my command!
Pack them up! Let's finish this!

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, Capitaine! Load those scraps into the catapults, boys! And just bear with it if it feels like something's biting you!
Ready here, Capitaine! The gremlins are loaded in the catapults!
Get, those creeps in the catapults, mes hommes! We're about to tear those Morganas a new hole!
Fire on my command! And... fire!
*LAUNCH*
Excellent!
Hourra! Take that, navires emmerdant!
That Béarn, she sure is...

Fields.MenuText: A good friend to have on my side.
A thoroughly incredible woman.
